channel.title: Programming Challenge #2
channel.description:
Okay, so I tried doing this for like half a day and couldn't figure it out, so I'm curious if any of you guys can.
Make a program that can take any music note input by the user and list the major scale associated with it, all of its relevant scales, and all the 1-3-5 chords from within those scales.

item.title: Programming Challenge #2
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:11, topic:519409”][quote author=Yesteryear link=topic=637871.msg4299780#msg4299780 date=1368801853]

notes = [ 'A', 'A#', 'B', 'C', 'C#', 'D', 'D#', 'E', 'F', 'F#', 'G', 'G#']
major_scale_steps = [2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 1, 2]

# request input
note = raw_input("Enter a note:\n")

note_index = notes.index(note)
major_scale = []

for step in major_scale_steps:
	major_scale.append(notes[note_index])
	note_index += step
	note_index %= len(notes)

chord = [major_scale[0], major_scale[2], major_scale[4]]

print note, 'Major scale: ',major_scale
print note, 'Chord: ',chord

input:

A
output:

A Major scale:  ['A', 'B', 'C#', 'D', 'E', 'F#', 'G#', 'A']
A Chord:  ['A', 'C#', 'E']

[/quote]

tigerclan and I already came up with semi-working solutions. We got almost everything to work (e.g. all the modes and keys), but the hard part was dealing with enharmonic equivalencies (e.g. there shouldn’t be an A# in the subdominant interval of an F major scale; rather, it should be a Bb). You can see my semi-solution on my GitHub if you want (tigerclan’s is on his page too.)[/quote]

Yeah which is the entire problem.

Although that code there isnt a bad start

edit: heres from my git, what i had last week. dunno why the major is all loveed up though

package mti;

/**
* @author Danny Barrett
*/

public class Main {

	String[] naturals = {
		"C", "D", "E", "F", "G", "A", "B"
	};
	int[] major = {
		1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2
	};

	public static void main(String args[]) {
		Main main = new Main();
		main.printMajor("A");
		System.out.println();
	}
	
	void printMajor(String root) {
		String[] scale = new String[7];
		int rootNumber = 0;
		int offset = 0;
		for(int i = 0; i < 7; i++) {
			if(naturals[i].equalsIgnoreCase(root)) {
				rootNumber = i;
				break;
			}
		}
		for(int j = 0; j < 7; j++) {
			if((rootNumber + j) > 6) {
				offset = (rootNumber + j - 7);
				if(major[j] == 2 && major[offset] == 1)
					scale[j] = naturals[offset] + "#";
				else if(major[j] == 1 && major[offset] == 2)
					scale[j] = naturals[offset] + "b";
				else
					scale[j] = naturals[offset];
			} else {
				offset = (rootNumber + j);
				if(major[j] == 2 && major[offset] == 1)
					scale[j] = naturals[offset] + "#";
				/*else if(major[j] == 1 && major[offset] == 2)
					scale[j] = naturals[offset] + "b";*/
				else
					scale[j] = naturals[offset];
			}
		}
		for(int k = 0; k < 7; k++) {
			System.out.print(scale[k] + " ");
		}
	}

}

Also for anyone whos wondering for clarification, the desired output(in C for simplicity) would be:

C Major: C D E F G A B
D Dorian: D E F G A B C
E Phrygian: E F G A B C D
F Lydian: F G A B C D E
G Mixolydian: G A B C D E F
A Minor: A B C D E F G
B Locrian(or Diminished): B C D E F G A

C (C E G)
Dm (D F A)
Em (E G B)
F (F A C)
G (G B D)
Am (A C E)
Bdim (B D F)
